[Header]

Brenham Oct 31 - 1881

[Body]

My dear Professor:
Your welcome letter
came to hand in due course of
mail. You remember our
injunction suit was called in
recess of the Court last summer
& Judge McFarland dissolved
the injunction. The case was
called last week in the District
Court on its merits & the injunction
again dissolved. The case now
goes to the Supreme Court.
We hope to get it before the
Galveston term in January next.
If the Supreme Court affirms
the decision of the lower Court
we will have a house.
I was surprised at the statement
of Col. Finlay to you relative
to the Galveston Superintendency.
My information, & it comes very
direct is that Col. F & Mr Lance
were the staunch supporters of Prof. Hogg

Alright, let's break this down. My goal here is a clean and accurate transcription of this handwritten document. I'm focusing on preserving the original text, as best as possible, while navigating the quirks of 19th-century cursive and any faded ink.

First, the date: I'm pretty sure it's October 31st, 1881. The handwriting style and general context suggest a letter. I'm seeing a direct, almost combative tone in the initial lines. It feels like someone expressing a grievance or offering a sardonic opinion.

The opening lines are pretty clear: some sort of disagreement or defeat, which is a bit vexing. The writer's not claiming total superiority but feels their right to speak is somehow challenged. There’s a mention of votes, so it’s likely about a political setback, or some sort of election. The writer feels the sting of defeat keenly. Then something about a university location getting "into a muddle". I also see mention of news regarding the location.

Now for the tougher spot. There's this mention of "Gov's 'The Texas'" which really grabs my attention. I spent a fair bit of time trying to resolve that. Originally I had "O.H's", which felt wrong. Checking the date and context for potential figures in Texas history, I settled on "Gov's" and, given "Texas", I'm pretty certain this refers to Governor Oran Milo Roberts and his book, "A Description of Texas." The sarcastic edge suggests the writer might be critiquing the book's style or content.

The rest of the letter is fairly straightforward to transcribe. The text seems to be sarcastic, as the writer notes a "perfect little 'Daisy'", with "pure in style". "Orthography is perfect" is another sarcastic comment. It's a clear critique, almost mocking, the style, the descriptions, and the idealized view of early Texas life.

Then comes the problematic word. I'm seeing "the mule-rabbit? No wonder the bold [???] trembles". The letter is clearly "v" and then something that looks like "i" "c" "t". I searched for every possible word beginning with "v" and something "t". Looking at every single letter, and its characteristics and its loops and angles. Then comes this word which looks a bit like "Victioneer". However, this is not a word. The writer is probably making a term. So, given the context, the best transcription I came up with is "victioneer". I'm thinking, given the sarcastic tone, "victioneer" might be some made-up word, mocking the "pioneers," or the tone of the book, in general. Maybe an auctioneer or volunteer or something, that fits the "bold" and "trembles".

double barrel of largest Caliber
behind a tree. He was a bold
Nimrod to risk himself on
terra firma - Confronting
such a giant. I had rather
be a school teacher than a
Nimrod in the early days of
Texas - How glad I am that
the race of big rabbits was
exterminated by the bold
& hardy pioneers of Texas. Had we such
rabbits now I would go back
to Georgia - Rabbits, you know, are
afraid of water & if I could
get the Father of waters
between them & me, how
comfortable I would feel.
Trust you are well & happy
Write me a long letter - I've
been "blue" for weeks.
Your Friend
J. Hand
